Cost-Effective Federated Learning in
Mobile Edge Networks

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a distributed learning paradigm that enables a large number of mobile devices to collaboratively learn a model under the coordination of a central server without sharing their raw data. Despite its practical efficiency and effectiveness, the iterative on-device learning process (e.g., local computations and global communications with the server) incurs a considerable cost in terms of learning time and energy consumption, which depends crucially on the number of selected clients and the number of local iterations in each training round. In this paper, we analyze how to design adaptive FL in mobile edge networks that optimally chooses these essential control variables to minimize the total cost while ensuring convergence. We establish the analytical relationship between the total cost and the control variables with the convergence upper bound. To efficiently solve the cost minimization problem, we develop a low-cost sampling-based algorithm to learn the convergence related unknown parameters. We derive important solution properties that effectively identify the design principles for different optimization metrics. Practically, we evaluate our theoretical results both in a simulated environment and on a hardware prototype. Experimental evidence verifies our derived properties and demonstrates that our proposed solution achieves near-optimal performance for different optimization metrics for various datasets and heterogeneous system and statistical settings.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, mobile edge networks, cost analysis, scheduling, optimization algorithm.

I Introduction

With the rapid advancement of Internet of Things (IoT) and social networking applications, there is an exponential increase of data generated at network edge devices, such as smartphones, IoT devices, and sensors [2]. These valuable data provide highly useful information for the prediction, classification, and other intelligent applications, which can improve our daily lives [3]. To analyze and exploit the large amount of data, standard machine learning (ML) techniques normally require collecting the training data in a central server. However, such centralized data collection and training can be quite challenging to perform due to limited communication bandwidth and data privacy concerns [4, 5].

To tackle this challenge, Federated learning (FL) has emerged as an attractive distributed learning paradigm, which enables many clients111Depending on the type of clients, FL can be categorized into cross-device FL and cross-silo FL (clients are companies or organizations, etc.) [6]. This paper focuses on the former and we use ‚Äúdevice‚Äù and ‚Äúclient‚Äù interchangeably. to collaboratively train a model under the coordination of a central server, while keeping the training data decentralized and private[7, 6]. In FL settings, the training data are in general massively distributed over a large number of clients, and the communications between the server and clients are typically operated at lower rates compared to datacenter settings. These unique features necessitate FL algorithms to perform multiple local iterations in parallel on a fraction of randomly sampled clients and then aggregate the resulting model update via the central server periodically [7].222Model compression is also an effective approach for improving FL communication efficiency. While orthogonal to the focus of this work, standard compression approaches such as sketched or random masking and model pruning [8, 6] can be used together to further reduce the cost.

FL has demonstrated its effectiveness in various statistically heterogeneous settings, e.g., unbalanced and non-independent and identically distributed (non-i.i.d.) data [9, 10, 11, 12]. Nevertheless, an efficient deployment of FL in mobile edge networks also needs to consider system heterogeneity. This is because in mobile edge environment, the system bandwidth is limited and shared by all connected mobile devices with potential mutual interference. Moreover, the selected devices may have different computational capabilities and dynamic wireless channel conditions due to mobility and channel fading, thus an efficient scheduling strategy in FL should adapt to system heterogeneity.

Because model training and information transmission for on-device FL can be both time and energy consuming, it is necessary and important to analyze the cost that is incurred for completing a given FL task. In general, the cost of FL includes multiple components such as learning time and energy consumption [13]. The importance of different cost components depends on the characteristics of FL systems and applications. For example, in a solar-based sensor network, energy consumption is the major concern for the sensors to participate in FL tasks, whereas in a multi-agent search-and-rescue task where the goal is to collaboratively learn an unknown map, achieving timely result would be the first priority. Therefore, a cost-effective FL design needs to jointly optimize various cost components (e.g., learning time and energy consumption) for different preferences.

A way of optimizing the cost is to adapt control variables in the FL process to achieve a properly defined objective. For example, some existing works have considered the adaptation of communication interval (i.e., the number of local iterations between two global aggregation rounds) for communication-efficient FL with convergence guarantees [14, 15]. However, a limitation in these works is that they only adapt a single control variable (i.e., communication interval) in the FL process and ignore other essential aspects, such as the number of participating clients in each round, which can have a significant impact on the energy consumption.

In this paper, we consider a multivariate control problem for wireless FL with convergence guarantees. To minimize the expected cost, we develop an algorithm that adapts these control variables in the FL process to achieve our goal. Compared to the univariate setting in existing works, our multivariate control problem is much more challenging due to the following reasons: 1)¬†The choices of control variables are tightly coupled due to system and statistical heterogeneity. 2)¬†The relationship between the control variables and the learning convergence rate has only been captured by an upper bound with unknown coefficients in the literature. 3) Our cost objective includes multiple components (e.g., time and energy) which can have different importance depending on the application scenario, whereas existing works often consider a single optimization objective, e.g., minimizing the communication overhead. In light of the above discussion, we state the key contributions of this work as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Cost-effective Wireless FL Design: This work, for the first time, analyzes how to design adaptive FL that optimally chooses the number of participating clients (Kùêæ{K}) and the number of local iterations (Eùê∏{E}) to minimize the total cost in mobile edge networks. Considering the wireless bandwidth limitation and interference, we propose a new scheduling scheme, as illustrated in Fig.¬†1, which characterizes both computation and communication heterogeneity.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Optimization Algorithm: We establish the analytical relationship between the total cost, control variables, heterogeneous system parameters, and convergence upper bound, based on which we formulate and analyze the optimization problem for total cost minimization. When facing the challenging issue of estimating the unknown coefficients in the convergence bound, we develop an effective sampling-based algorithm to learn these parameters with a small estimation overhead.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Theoretical Properties: We obtain important analytical properties that effectively identify the design principles of KùêæK and Eùê∏E for different optimization metrics and heterogeneous system parameters. Notably, the choice of KùêæK leads to an interesting trade-off between learning time reduction and energy saving, with a relatively large KùêæK favoring the former while K=1ùêæ1K=1 always benefiting the latter. In contrast, the total cost, no matter emphasizing learning time or energy consumption, always first decreases and then increases in Eùê∏E. We also show how heterogeneous system parameters in terms of computation and communication affect the optimal KùêæK and Eùê∏E.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Simulation and Experimentation: We evaluate our theoretical results with real and synthetic heterogeneous datasets, both in a simulated wireless cellular network and on a WiFi-based hardware prototype. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed optimization algorithm provides near-optimal solution for different optimization metrics, and verify our theoretical findings for design principles and solution properties.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. We first present the related work in Section¬†II. Then, we present the system model and problem formulation in Section¬†III. In Section¬†IV, we analyze the cost minimization problem and present an algorithm to solve it. We provide theoretical analysis on the solution properties in Section¬†V. Experimentation results are given in Section¬†VI and the conclusion is presented in Section¬†VII.

II Related Work

FL was first proposed in [7], which demonstrated FL‚Äôs effectiveness of collaboratively learning a model without collecting users‚Äô data. The de facto FL algorithm is federated averaging (FedAvg), which performs multiple local iterations in parallel on a subset of devices in each round. A system-level FL framework [9] demonstrates the empirical success of FedAvg in mobile devices. Recently, a convergence bound of FedAvg was established in [10]. Other related distributed optimization algorithms are mostly analyzed for homogeneous and i.i.d. datasets (e.g., [16, 17, 18]) and full client participation (e.g., [19, 20]), which do not capture the essence of on-device FL. Some extensions of FedAvg considered aspects such as adding a proximal term¬†[21], using gradient descent acceleration¬†[22], variance reduction (e.g., [23, 24]), or fine tuning hyper-parameters¬†[25, 26]. While novel insights are provided in these works, they did not consider optimization for cost/resource efficiency.

Literature in FL cost optimization mainly focused on learning time and on-device energy consumption in mobile edge networks. The optimization of learning time was studied in [27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32, 33, 8], and joint optimization for learning time and energy consumption was considered in [34, 35, 36, 37]. These works considered resource (e.g., transmission power, communication bandwidth, and CPU frequency) allocation (e.g., [27, 28, 34, 35, 36, 37]), cost-aware client selection (e.g., [29, 30]), client scheduling (e.g., [31, 32, 33]), and model pruning[8] for pre-specified (i.e., non-optimized) design parameters (KùêæK and Eùê∏E in our case) of the FL algorithm.

The optimization of a single design parameter Eùê∏E was studied in¬†[14, 15, 38, 39, 40], most of which assume full client participation and can be infeasible for large-scale on-device FL. A very recent work in [41] considered the optimization of both Eùê∏E and client selection for additive per-client costs. However, the cost of learning time in our problem is non-additive on a per-client basis, since different clients perform local model updates in parallel. In addition, the convergence bound used in¬†[41] (also¬†[13]) is for a primal-dual optimization algorithm, which is different from the commonly used FedAvg algorithm. The challenge in optimizing both KùêæK and Eùê∏E for cost minimization of FedAvg, which also distinguishes our work from the above, is the need to analytically connect the total cost with the control variables as well as with the convergence rate. The comparison of our work with the above related works is illustrated in Table¬†I, where we note that our optimization design is orthogonal to most works on resource allocation in the last column in Table¬†I and can be used together with those techniques to further reduce the cost.

In addition, most existing work on FL are based on simulations, whereas we implement our algorithm in an actual hardware prototype with resource-constrained devices.

III System Model and Problem Formulation

We start by summarizing the basics of FL and its de facto algorithm FedAvg. Then, we introduce the scheduling strategy when applying FL in mobile edge networks with system heterogeneity. Finally, we present the cost optimization problem for FL tasks. We summarize all key notations in this paper in Table¬†II.

III-A Federated Learning

Consider a scenario with a large number of mobile clients that have data for training a machine learning model. Due to data privacy concern, it is not desirable for clients to disclose and send their raw data to a high-performance data center. FL is a decentralized learning framework that aims to resolve this problem. Mathematically, FL is the following distributed optimization problem:

FedAvg (Algorithm¬†1) was proposed in [7] to solve (1). In each round¬†rùëür, a subset of randomly selected clients ùí¶rsuperscriptùí¶ùëü\mathcal{K}^{r} run Eùê∏E steps333Eùê∏E is originally defined as epochs of SGD in [7]. Then, the updated model parameters of these |ùí¶r|superscriptùí¶ùëü\left|\mathcal{K}^{r}\right| clients are sent to and aggregated by the server. This process repeats for many rounds until the global loss converges.

FL has demonstrated its effectiveness in tackling with statistical heterogeneity, e.g., unbalanced and non-i.i.d. data distribution. Meanwhile, applying it in practical mobile edge networks also needs to address clients‚Äô computational and communication heterogeneity. Therefore, an efficient FL design requires joint consideration of statistical and system heterogeneity.

III-B Deploying Federated Learning in Mobile Edge Networks

In mobile edge networks, due to system bandwidth limitation and wireless interference, participating clients are usually scheduled in a time-sharing (TS) [13, 34] or frequency-sharing (FS) [30, 27, 36] protocols.444We consider cellular network based one-hop communication between the server and the clients, since its topology is well-aligned with that in mainstream FL community. For FL in a decentralized topology, e.g., in wireless ad-hoc networks, the communications could be multi-hop, which is beyond our focus in this work. Although leveraging analog aggregation techniques in wireless communications [42, 43, 44] can increase the communication efficiency, it may require stringent synchronization and additional superposition code design. However, the selected heterogeneous clients may have diverse communication and computation capabilities, which results in different per-round training time under different scheduling strategies, especially for clients with dynamic wireless channels. This is because the per-round time depends on the slowest client (known as straggler), as the server needs to collect all updates from the sampled clients before performing global aggregation.

In this paper, as shown in Fig. 1, we propose a new TS based FL model which works efficiently with heterogeneous computation and communication time. We note that the empirical results in Section¬†VI demonstrate that our proposed TS is superior to existing FS schemes in [42, 43, 44]. The main reason is that, in those FS schemes, the frequency allocation for the sampled clients in each round is static, which causes a waste in bandwidth resources. This is because, due to computational heterogeneity, clients who complete computation early can be allocated with more bandwidth for transmission before the next client completing computation, instead of always sharing the entire bandwidth static with other slower clients. In the following, we first describe our system model and then present the proposed TS protocol.

III-B1 System Model

Similar to existing works [7, 10, 21], we sample KùêæK clients in each round rùëür (i.e., K:=|ùí¶r|,1‚â§K‚â§Nformulae-sequenceassignùêæsuperscriptùí¶ùëü1ùêæùëÅK:=\left|\mathcal{K}^{r}\right|,{1\leq K\leq N}), where the sampling is uniform at random (without replacement) out of all NùëÅN clients. Similar to existing studies on wireless FL (e.g., [30, 27, 36]), we assume that a particular device has the same computation cost (time and energy) over multiple rounds, whereas the communication cost varies between rounds due to wireless dynamics. We do not consider the server‚Äôs downlink cost for model broadcasting and model aggregation, as we mainly focus on the performance bottleneck of the battery-constrained edge devices.

III-B2 Proposed Time-sharing Protocol

Consider a general round rùëür, where the server (co-located with the base station) first broadcasts the current global model to the randomly selected ùí¶rsuperscriptùí¶ùëü\mathcal{K}^{r} clients. Then, each of the selected clients performs Eùê∏E steps of local iterations in parallel, where we denote tk,psubscriptùë°ùëòùëùt_{k,p} as the computation time for client kùëòk to perform one local iteration. In the communication phase, however, the selected clients sequentially upload their model to the server in different time slots, where we denote tk,mrsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëöùëüt_{k,m}^{r} as the communication time for client kùëòk to upload the model parameter in round rùëür.555We note that tk,mrsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëöùëüt_{k,m}^{r} can be calculated by tk,mr=Œ©/Blog(1+pk‚Äãh¬ØkrN0)t_{k,m}^{r}=\left.{\Omega}\middle/{B\log\left({1+\frac{p_{k}\bar{h}_{k}^{r}}{N_{0}}}\right)}\right., where Œ©Œ©\Omega is the size of model parameter, BùêµB is the bandwidth, pksubscriptùëùùëòp_{k} is the transmission power (we do not consider power control in this work, though it can be incorporated in future work), h¬Økrsuperscriptsubscript¬Ø‚Ñéùëòùëü\bar{h}_{k}^{r} is the average channel gain of the client kùëòk during the FL training time in round rùëür and N0subscriptùëÅ0N_{0} is the white noise power.

Due to the difference between tk,psubscriptùë°ùëòùëùt_{k,p} and tk,mrsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëöùëüt_{k,m}^{r} among the selected KùêæK clients in ùí¶rsuperscriptùí¶ùëü\mathcal{K}^{r}, the time of round rùëür depends on the scheduling order of the KùêæK clients. We present the optimal TS scheduling with the following theorem, which achieves the minimum time for a particular round rùëür with the selected clients ùí¶rsuperscriptùí¶ùëü\mathcal{K}^{r}. We note that the proposed scheduling scheme mainly considers the total learning time for the sampled clients rather than their energy consumption. This is because the total energy consumption is the sum of all sampled clients‚Äô energy cost, which is independent of the scheduling order of the KùêæK clients.

Compared to existing TS scheduling strategy in [13] where communication from the clients to the server will not begin until all sampled clients complete local iterations, the scheduling policy specified in Theorem¬†1 enables each client to upload its result to the server as soon as it finishes the computation when the wireless channel is available, which potentially reduces system waiting time and thus the round time TrsuperscriptùëáùëüT^{r}. The max function in (3) characterizes whether the channel is vacant when a certain client completes its local iteration, e.g., the red shadow time slots in Fig.¬†1.

III-C Cost Analysis of Federated Learning in Mobile Edge Networks

Despite the effectiveness and efficiency of FL, practitioners need to take into account the cost of completing FL tasks. The total cost of FL, according to Fig.¬†1, involves learning time and energy consumption, both of which are consumed during local computation and global communication in each round.

III-C1 Time Cost

Based on the optimal TS scheduling in Theorem 1, the per-round time after scheduling the selected KùêæK clients is TrsuperscriptùëáùëüT^{r}, which depends on the number of sampled clients KùêæK and the number of location computation steps Eùê∏E. The total learning time TtotsubscriptùëátotT_{\textnormal{tot}} after RùëÖR rounds is

Ttot‚Äã(K,E,R)=‚àër=1RTr.subscriptùëátotùêæùê∏ùëÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëü1ùëÖsuperscriptùëáùëüT_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)=\sum\nolimits_{r=1}^{R}T^{r}. (4)

III-C2 Energy Cost

Similar to the notation for time cost, by denoting eksubscriptùëíùëòe_{k} as the per-round energy consumption for client kùëòk to complete the computation and communication, we have

ekr=ek,p‚ÄãE+ek,mr,superscriptsubscriptùëíùëòùëüsubscriptùëíùëòùëùùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëíùëòùëöùëüe_{k}^{r}=e_{k,p}E+e_{k,m}^{r}, (5)

where ek,psubscriptùëíùëòùëùe_{k,p} is the computation energy for client kùëòk to perform one step local iteration in each round, and ek,mrsuperscriptsubscriptùëíùëòùëöùëüe_{k,m}^{r} is client kùëòk‚Äôs communication energy in round rùëür due to wireless dynamics.

Unlike the per-round time cost, the energy cost ersuperscriptùëíùëüe^{r} in each round rùëür depends on the sum energy consumption of the selected KùêæK clients. Therefore, the total energy cost etotsubscriptùëítote_{\textnormal{tot}} after RùëÖR rounds can be expressed as

III-D Problem Formulation

Considering the difference of the two cost metrics, the optimal solutions of KùêæK, Eùê∏E and RùëÖR generally do not achieve the common goal for minimizing both TtotsubscriptùëátotT_{\textnormal{tot}} and etotsubscriptùëítote_{\textnormal{tot}}. To strike the balance between learning time and energy consumption, we introduce a weight Œ≥‚àà[0,1]ùõæ01\gamma\in\left[0,1\right] and optimize the balanced cost function in the following form:

Ctot‚Äã(K,E,R)=Œ≥‚Äãetot‚Äã(K,E,R)+(1‚àíŒ≥)‚ÄãTtot‚Äã(K,E,R),subscriptùê∂totùêæùê∏ùëÖùõæsubscriptùëítotùêæùê∏ùëÖ1ùõæsubscriptùëátotùêæùê∏ùëÖC_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)=\gamma e_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)+\left(1-\gamma\right)T_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R), (7)

where 1‚àíŒ≥1ùõæ1-\gamma and Œ≥ùõæ\gamma can be interpreted as the normalized price of the two costs, i.e., how much monetary cost for one unit of time and one unit of energy, respectively. The value of Œ≥ùõæ\gamma can be adjusted for different preferences. For example, we can set Œ≥=0ùõæ0\gamma=0 when all clients are plugged in and energy consumption is not a major concern, whereas Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1 when devices are solar-based sensors where saving the devices‚Äô energy is the priority.

Our goal is to minimize the expected total cost while ensuring convergence, which translates into this problem:

P1:minE,K,Rùîº‚Äã[Ctot‚Äã(E,K,R)]¬†s.t.¬†ùîº‚Äã[F‚Äã(ùê∞R)]‚àíF‚àó‚â§œµ,K,E,R‚àà‚Ñ§+,and‚Äã 1‚â§K‚â§N.P1:subscriptùê∏ùêæùëÖùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂totùê∏ùêæùëÖ¬†s.t.¬†ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπsubscriptùê∞ùëÖsuperscriptùêπitalic-œµmissing-subexpressionformulae-sequenceùêæùê∏ùëÖsuperscript‚Ñ§and1ùêæùëÅ\begin{array}[]{cl}\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\textbf{P1:}\quad\quad\min_{E,K,R}&\mathbb{E}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}(E,K,R)]\\ \quad\quad\text{ s.t. }&\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{R})]-F^{*}\leq\epsilon,\\ &K,E,R\in\mathbb{Z}^{+},\ \text{and}\ \ 1\leq K\leq N.\end{array} (8)

where ùîº‚Äã[F‚Äã(ùê∞R)]ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπsubscriptùê∞ùëÖ\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{R})] is the expected loss after RùëÖR rounds, F‚àósuperscriptùêπF^{*} is the (true and unknown) minimum value of FùêπF, and œµitalic-œµ\epsilon is the desired precision. We note that the expectation in Problem P1 takes over three source of randomness, where the first two randomness come from the client sampling and data sampling in SGD in each round, and the third randomness comes from the varying communication cost in each round due to dynamic wireless channel conditions.

Solving Problem P1 is challenging in two aspects. First, it is difficult to find an exact analytical expression to relate KùêæK, Eùê∏E and RùëÖR with Ctotsubscriptùê∂totC_{\textnormal{tot}}, especially due to the maximum function in TtotsubscriptùëátotT_{\textnormal{tot}}. Second, it is generally impossible to obtain an exact analytical relationship to connect KùêæK, Eùê∏E and RùëÖR with the convergence constraint. In the following section, we propose an algorithm that approximately solves Problem P1, which we later show with extensive experiments that the proposed solution can achieve a near-optimal performance of Problem P1.

IV Cost-Effective Optimization Algorithm

This section shows how to approximately solve Problem P1. We first formulate an alternative problem that includes an approximate analytical relationship between the expected cost ùîº‚Äã[Ctot]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂tot\mathbb{E}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}], the convergence constraint, and the control variables Eùê∏E, KùêæK and RùëÖR. Then, we show that this new optimization problem can be efficiently solved after estimating unknown parameters associated with the convergence bound, and we propose a sampling-based algorithm to learn these unknown parameters.

IV-A Approximate Solution to Problem P1

IV-A1 Analytical Expression of ùîº‚Äã[etot]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëítot\mathbb{E}[e_{\textnormal{tot}}]

We first analytically establish the expected energy cost ùîº‚Äã[etot]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëítot\mathbb{E}[e_{\textnormal{tot}}] with KùêæK and Eùê∏E.

Lemma 1.

The expectation of etotsubscriptùëítote_{\textnormal{tot}} in (6) can be expressed as

ùîº‚Äã[etot‚Äã(K,E,R)]=K‚Äã(ep‚ÄãE+em)‚ÄãR,ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëítotùêæùê∏ùëÖùêæsubscriptùëíùëùùê∏subscriptùëíùëöùëÖ\mathbb{E}[e_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)]=K\left(e_{p}E+e_{m}\right)R, (9)

where ep:=‚àëk=1Nek,pNassignsubscriptùëíùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëÅsubscriptùëíùëòùëùùëÅe_{p}\!:=\!\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{N}e_{k,p}}{N} and em:=‚àëk=1N‚àër=1Rek,mrN‚ÄãRassignsubscriptùëíùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëü1ùëÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëíùëòùëöùëüùëÅùëÖe_{m}\!:=\!\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{N}\sum_{r=1}^{R}{e}_{k,m}^{r}}{NR} denote the average per-device energy consumption for one local iteration and one round of communication, respectively.

Proof.

Given that all devices are sampled uniformly at random in each round and each round KùêæK out of NùëÅN clients are sampled, thus for RùëÖR rounds, each device will be sampled in K‚ÄãRNùêæùëÖùëÅ\frac{KR}{N} rounds in expectation. Based on the result in (5) that each device kùëòk consumes ek,p‚ÄãE+ek,mrsubscriptùëíùëòùëùùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëíùëòùëöùëüe_{k,p}E+{e}_{k,m}^{r} energy in each round, summing up ek,p‚ÄãE+ek,mrsubscriptùëíùëòùëùùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëíùëòùëöùëüe_{k,p}E+{e}_{k,m}^{r} over all NùëÅN clients and over K‚ÄãRNùêæùëÖùëÅ\frac{KR}{N} rounds lead to (9). ‚àé

IV-A2 Analytical Expression of ùîº‚Äã[Ttot]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátot\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}]

Next, we give an approximate expression of the expected time cost ùîº‚Äã[Ttot]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátot\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}] with KùêæK and Eùê∏E. In the following, we first show how to approximate the per-round time TrsuperscriptùëáùëüT^{r} in (3), based on which we formulate a combinatorial expression of expected TtotsubscriptùëátotT_{\textnormal{tot}} in (4). Then, we further approximate the expectation of TtotsubscriptùëátotT_{\textnormal{tot}} for analytical tractability.

Considering that the communication time is usually the bottleneck in wireless FL settings, it is most likely that the maximum in (3) is equal to Tk‚àí1rsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëò1ùëüT_{k-1}^{r} for any k‚àà{2,‚Ä¶,K}ùëò2‚Ä¶ùêæk\in\{2,\ldots,K\}, e.g., the red shadow time slot in Fig.¬†1 rarely happens. In other words, the communication channel will be usually occupied after the fastest client (e.g., k=1ùëò1k=1 in the KùêæK clients reordered as in Theorem¬†1) finishes computation. Therefore, TrsuperscriptùëáùëüT^{r} in (3) can be approximated by

Tr‚âàt1,p‚ÄãE+‚àëk=1Ktk,mr.superscriptùëáùëüsubscriptùë°1ùëùùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëöùëüT^{r}\approx{t_{1,p}}E+\sum_{k=1}^{K}{t_{k,m}^{r}}. (10)

Note that the ordering of {tk,p:‚àÄk‚ààùí¶r}conditional-setsubscriptùë°ùëòùëùfor-allùëòsuperscriptùí¶ùëü\{t_{k,p}:\forall k\in\mathcal{K}^{r}\} varies across different rounds due to random sampling, i.e., the client with index k=1ùëò1k=1 may be different in different rounds. With a slight abuse of notation, we use ti,psubscriptùë°ùëñùëùt_{i,p} to denote the iùëñi-th fastest client (in terms of computation) out of all NùëÅN clients (i.e., before sampling), such that

t1,p‚â§t2,p‚â§‚Ä¶‚â§ti,p‚â§‚Ä¶‚â§tN,p.subscriptùë°1ùëùsubscriptùë°2ùëù‚Ä¶subscriptùë°ùëñùëù‚Ä¶subscriptùë°ùëÅùëùt_{1,p}\leq t_{2,p}\leq\ldots\leq t_{i,p}\leq\ldots\leq t_{N,p}. (11)
Lemma 2.

With the reordered clients as in (11) and the approximate TrsuperscriptùëáùëüT^{r} as in (10), the expectation of TtotsubscriptùëátotT_{\textnormal{tot}} in (4) can be expressed as666The notation of CNKsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùêæC_{N}^{K} is also noted as (NK)binomialùëÅùêæ\binom{N}{K} which represents the combination number of choosing KùêæK out of NùëÅN without replacement.

ùîº‚Äã[Ttot‚Äã(K,E,R)]‚âà(‚àëi=1N‚àíi+1CN‚àíii‚àí1‚Äãti,pCNK‚ÄãE+tm‚ÄãK)‚ÄãR,ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátotùêæùê∏ùëÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅùëñ1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùëñùëñ1subscriptùë°ùëñùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùêæùê∏subscriptùë°ùëöùêæùëÖ\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)]\approx\left(\frac{\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N-i+1}{C_{N-i}^{i-1}}t_{i,p}}{C_{N}^{K}}E+t_{m}K\right)R, (12)

We give the full proof in Appendix B. The basic idea is to show the expectation of TrsuperscriptùëáùëüT^{r} in (10) is ùîº‚Äã[Tr]‚âà‚àëi=1N‚àíK+1CN‚àíiK‚àí1‚Äãti,pCNK‚ÄãE+tm‚ÄãK,ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptùëáùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅùêæ1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùëñùêæ1subscriptùë°ùëñùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùêæùê∏subscriptùë°ùëöùêæ\mathbb{E}[T^{r}]\approx\frac{\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N-K+1}{C_{N-i}^{K-1}}t_{i,p}}{C_{N}^{K}}E+t_{m}K, where ‚àëi=1N‚àíK+1CN‚àíiK‚àí1‚Äãti,pCNK‚ÄãEsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅùêæ1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùëñùêæ1subscriptùë°ùëñùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùêæùê∏\frac{\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N-K+1}{C_{N-i}^{K-1}}t_{i,p}}{C_{N}^{K}}E represents that the probability of client iùëñi being the first scheduling client is CN‚àíiK‚àí1CNKsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùëñùêæ1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùêæ\frac{{C_{N-i}^{K-1}}}{C_{N}^{K}}, and the second term tm‚ÄãKsubscriptùë°ùëöùêæt_{m}K is derived similar to emsubscriptùëíùëöe_{m} in Lemma 1. In particular, the multiplication of KùêæK in tm‚ÄãKsubscriptùë°ùëöùêæt_{m}K characterizes the scheduling property of wireless communications with limited bandwidth.

However, ùîº‚Äã[Ttot]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátot\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}] in (12) is still hard to analyze due to the various combinatorial terms with respect to control variable KùêæK. For analytical tractability, similar to how we derive (9), we define an approximation of ùîº‚Äã[Ttot]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátot\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}] as

ùîº~‚Äã[Ttot‚Äã(K,E,R)]:=(tp‚ÄãE+tm‚ÄãK)‚ÄãR,assign~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátotùêæùê∏ùëÖsubscriptùë°ùëùùê∏subscriptùë°ùëöùêæùëÖ\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)]:=\left(t_{p}E+t_{m}K\right)R, (13)

where tp:=‚àëi=1Nti,pNassignsubscriptùë°ùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùë°ùëñùëùùëÅt_{p}:=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}t_{i,p}}{N} is the average per-device time cost for one local iteration. The approximation ùîº~‚Äã[Ttot]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}] in (13) is equivalent to ùîº‚Äã[Ttot]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátot\mathbb{E}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}] in (12) in the following two cases.

ùîº‚Äã[Ttot‚Äã(K,E,R)]=(tp‚ÄãE‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚àíK+1CN‚àíiK‚àí1CNK+tm‚ÄãK)‚ÄãR=(tp‚ÄãE+tm‚ÄãK)‚ÄãR=ùîº~‚Äã[Ttot‚Äã(K,E,R)].ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátotùêæùê∏ùëÖabsentsubscriptùë°ùëùùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅùêæ1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùëñùêæ1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùêæsubscriptùë°ùëöùêæùëÖmissing-subexpressionabsentsubscriptùë°ùëùùê∏subscriptùë°ùëöùêæùëÖmissing-subexpressionabsent~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátotùêæùê∏ùëÖ\begin{array}[]{cl}\mathbb{E}[{T_{\textnormal{tot}}}(K,E,R)]&=\left(t_{p}E\frac{\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N-K+1}{C_{N-i}^{K-1}}}{C_{N}^{K}}+t_{m}K\right)R\\ &=\left(t_{p}E+t_{m}K\right)R\\ &=\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)].\end{array}

ùîº‚Äã[Ttot‚Äã(K=1,E,R)]=(‚àëi=1Nti,p‚ÄãEN+tm‚ÄãK)‚ÄãR=(tp‚ÄãE+tm‚ÄãK)‚ÄãR=ùîº~‚Äã[Ttot‚Äã(K=1,E,R)].ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátotùêæ1ùê∏ùëÖabsentsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùë°ùëñùëùùê∏ùëÅsubscriptùë°ùëöùêæùëÖmissing-subexpressionabsentsubscriptùë°ùëùùê∏subscriptùë°ùëöùêæùëÖmissing-subexpressionabsent~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátotùêæ1ùê∏ùëÖ\begin{array}[]{cl}\mathbb{E}[{T_{\textnormal{tot}}}(K=1,E,R)]&=\left(\frac{\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N}{t_{i,p}E}}{N}+t_{m}K\right)R\\ &=\left(t_{p}E+t_{m}K\right)R\\ &=\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(K=1,E,R)].\end{array}

In the following cost analysis, we use ùîº~‚Äã[Ttot‚Äã(K,E,R)]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátotùêæùê∏ùëÖ\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)] in (13) as the approximate expected value of the original total learning time in (4).

IV-A3 Analytical Relationship Between ùîº‚Äã[Ctot]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂tot\mathbb{E}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] and Convergence

Based on ùîº‚Äã[etot]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëítot\mathbb{E}[e_{\textnormal{tot}}] in (9) and the approximation ùîº~‚Äã[Ttot‚Äã(K,E,R)]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëátotùêæùê∏ùëÖ\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[T_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)] in (13), we formulate an approximate objective function of Problem P1 as

ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]=(Œ≥‚ÄãK‚Äã(ep‚ÄãE+em)+(1‚àíŒ≥)‚Äã(tp‚ÄãE+tm‚ÄãK))‚ÄãR.~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂totùõæùêæsubscriptùëíùëùùê∏subscriptùëíùëö1ùõæsubscriptùë°ùëùùê∏subscriptùë°ùëöùêæùëÖ\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]=\left(\gamma K\left(e_{p}E+e_{m}\right)+\left(1-\gamma\right)\left(t_{p}E+t_{m}K\right)\right)R. (14)

To connect ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] with the œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-convergence constraint in (8) as well as to characterize the heterogeneous data, we utilize the convergence result [10]777We use the convergence result in [10] because both [10] and our work analyze the FedAvg algorithm, and the convergence result in [10] includes both control variables Eùê∏E and KùêæK for cost minimization. We also note that the convergence result in [10] requires clients to decay the learning rate throughout the training process, which we show later in Section VI.:

ùîº‚Äã[F‚Äã(ùê∞R)]‚àíF‚àó‚â§1E‚ÄãR‚Äã(A0+B0‚Äã(1+N‚àíKK‚Äã(N‚àí1))‚ÄãE2),ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπsubscriptùê∞ùëÖsuperscriptùêπ1ùê∏ùëÖsubscriptùê¥0subscriptùêµ01ùëÅùêæùêæùëÅ1superscriptùê∏2\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{R})]\!-\!F^{*}\leq\frac{1}{ER}\left(A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N\!-\!1)}\right)E^{2}\right), (15)

where A0subscriptùê¥0A_{0} and B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0} are loss function related constants characterizing the statistical heterogeneity of non-i.i.d. data. By letting the upper bound satisfy the convergence constraint,888We note that optimization using upper bound as an approximation has also been adopted in [14] and resource allocation based literature [13, 27, 36]. we approximate Problem P1 as

P2:‚ÄãminE,K,R(Œ≥‚ÄãK‚Äã(ep‚ÄãE+em)+(1‚àíŒ≥)‚Äã(tp‚ÄãE+tm‚ÄãK))‚ÄãR¬†s.t.¬†1E‚ÄãR‚Äã(A0+B0‚Äã(1+N‚àíKK‚Äã(N‚àí1))‚ÄãE2)‚â§œµK,E,R‚àà‚Ñ§+,and‚Äã 1‚â§K‚â§N.P2:subscriptùê∏ùêæùëÖùõæùêæsubscriptùëíùëùùê∏subscriptùëíùëö1ùõæsubscriptùë°ùëùùê∏subscriptùë°ùëöùêæùëÖ¬†s.t.¬†1ùê∏ùëÖsubscriptùê¥0subscriptùêµ01ùëÅùêæùêæùëÅ1superscriptùê∏2italic-œµmissing-subexpressionformulae-sequenceùêæùê∏ùëÖsuperscript‚Ñ§and1ùêæùëÅ\begin{array}[]{cl}\!\!\!\!\!\!\textbf{P2:}\ \min_{E,K,R}&\!\!\!\left(\gamma K\left(e_{p}E+e_{m}\right)+\left(1\!-\!\gamma\right)\left(t_{p}E+t_{m}K\right)\right)R\\ \quad\text{ s.t. }&\!\!\!\frac{1}{ER}\left(A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)E^{2}\right)\leq\epsilon\\ &K,E,R\in\mathbb{Z}^{+},\ \text{and}\ \ 1\leq K\leq N.\end{array} (16)

Combining with (15), we can see that Problem P2 is more constrained than Problem P1, as any feasible solution of P2 is also feasible for P1, but not vice versa.

Problem P2, however, is a non-linear constrained integer optimization problem, which is still difficult to solve in general. Therefore, we relax KùêæK, Eùê∏E and RùëÖR as continuous variables for theoretical analysis, which are rounded back to integer variables999For two integer variables we have four rounding combinations of (‚åàK‚åâ,‚åàE‚åâ)ùêæùê∏\left(\left\lceil{K}\right\rceil,\left\lceil{E}\right\rceil\right), (‚åàK‚åâ,‚åäE‚åã)ùêæùê∏\left(\left\lceil{K}\right\rceil,\left\lfloor{E}\right\rfloor\right), (‚åäK‚åã,‚åàE‚åâ)ùêæùê∏\left(\left\lfloor{K}\right\rfloor,\left\lceil{E}\right\rceil\right), and (‚åäK‚åã,‚åäE‚åã)ùêæùê∏\left(\left\lfloor{K}\right\rfloor,\left\lfloor{E}\right\rfloor\right). later. For the relaxed problem, if any feasible solution E‚Ä≤,K‚Ä≤superscriptùê∏‚Ä≤superscriptùêæ‚Ä≤E^{\prime},K^{\prime}, and R‚Ä≤superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤R^{\prime} satisfies the œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-constraint in Problem P2 with inequality, we can always decrease this R‚Ä≤superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤R^{\prime} to some R‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤R^{\prime\prime} (R‚Ä≤‚Ä≤<R‚Ä≤superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤R^{\prime\prime}<R^{\prime}), which satisfies the constraint with equality but reduces the objective function value. Hence, for optimal RùëÖR, the œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-constraint is always satisfied with equality, and we can obtain RùëÖR from this equality as

R=1œµ‚ÄãE‚Äã(A0+B0‚Äã(1+N‚àíKK‚Äã(N‚àí1))‚ÄãE2).ùëÖ1italic-œµùê∏subscriptùê¥0subscriptùêµ01ùëÅùêæùêæùëÅ1superscriptùê∏2R=\frac{1}{\epsilon E}\left(A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)E^{2}\right). (17)

By substituting (17) into problem P2, we obtain

P3:‚ÄãminE,K((1‚àíŒ≥)‚Äã(tp‚ÄãE+tm‚ÄãK)+Œ≥‚ÄãK‚Äã(ep‚ÄãE+em))‚ãÖ(A0+B0‚Äã(1+N‚àíKK‚Äã(N‚àí1))‚ÄãE2)œµ‚ÄãEs.t.E‚â•1,and‚Äã 1‚â§K‚â§N,P3:subscriptùê∏ùêæ1ùõæsubscriptùë°ùëùùê∏subscriptùë°ùëöùêæùõæùêæsubscriptùëíùëùùê∏subscriptùëíùëömissing-subexpression‚ãÖabsentsubscriptùê¥0subscriptùêµ01ùëÅùêæùêæùëÅ1superscriptùê∏2italic-œµùê∏s.t.formulae-sequenceùê∏1and1ùêæùëÅ\begin{array}[]{cl}\!\!\!\textbf{P3:}\ \min_{E,K}&\!\!\!\!\!\left(\left(1\!-\!\gamma\right)\left(t_{p}E+\!t_{m}K\right)\!+\!\gamma K\left(e_{p}E\!+\!e_{m}\right)\right)\\ &\cdot\frac{\left(\!A_{0}+B_{0}\left(\!1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\!\right)E^{2}\right)}{\epsilon E}\\ \!\!\!\!\!\quad\text{s.t.}&\!\!\!{E}\geq 1,\ \text{and}\ \ 1\leq K\leq N,\end{array} (18)

In the following, we solve Problem P3 as an approximation of the original problem P1. Our empirical results in Section¬†VI demonstrate that the solution obtained from solving P3 achieves near-optimal performance of the original problem P1. For ease of analysis, we incorporate œµitalic-œµ\epsilon in the constants A0subscriptùê¥0A_{0} and B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0}.

IV-B Solving the Approximate Optimization Problem P3

In this subsection, we first characterize some properties of the optimization problem P3. Then, we propose a sampling-based algorithm to learn the problem-related unknown parameters A0subscriptùê¥0A_{0} and B0subscriptùêµ0B_{0}, based on which the solution K‚àósuperscriptùêæK^{*} and E‚àósuperscriptùê∏E^{*} (of Problem P3) can be efficiently computed. The overall algorithm for obtaining K‚àósuperscriptùêæK^{*} and E‚àósuperscriptùê∏E^{*} is given in Algorithm¬†2.

IV-B1 Characterizing Problem P3

Theorem 2.

Problem P3 is strictly biconvex [45].

Proof.

For any E‚â•1ùê∏1E\geq 1, we have

‚àÇ2ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]‚àÇ2K=2‚Äã(1‚àíŒ≥)‚ÄãB0‚ÄãN‚Äãtp‚ÄãE2(N‚àí1)‚ÄãK3>0.superscript2~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂totsuperscript2ùêæ21ùõæsubscriptùêµ0ùëÅsubscriptùë°ùëùsuperscriptùê∏2ùëÅ1superscriptùêæ30\dfrac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}K}=\dfrac{2(1-\gamma)B_{0}Nt_{p}E^{2}}{(N-1)K^{3}}>0.

Similarly, for any 1‚â§K‚â§N1ùêæùëÅ1\leq K\leq N, we have

‚àÇ2ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]‚àÇ2E=2‚Äã((1‚àíŒ≥)‚Äãtp+Œ≥‚ÄãK‚Äãep)‚ÄãB0‚Äã(1+N‚àíKK‚Äã(N‚àí1))+2‚ÄãA0‚Äã((1‚àíŒ≥)‚ÄãK‚Äãtm+Œ≥‚ÄãK‚Äãem)E3>0superscript2~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂totsuperscript2ùê∏21ùõæsubscriptùë°ùëùùõæùêæsubscriptùëíùëùsubscriptùêµ01ùëÅùêæùêæùëÅ1missing-subexpression2subscriptùê¥01ùõæùêæsubscriptùë°ùëöùõæùêæsubscriptùëíùëösuperscriptùê∏30missing-subexpression\begin{array}[]{cl}\dfrac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}E}=2\left(\left(1-\gamma\right)t_{p}+\gamma Ke_{p}\right)B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)\\ \qquad+\dfrac{2A_{0}\left((1-\gamma)Kt_{m}+\gamma Ke_{m}\right)}{E^{3}}>0\end{array} (19)

Since the domain of KùêæK and Eùê∏E is convex, we conclude that Problem P3 is strictly biconvex. ‚àé

The biconvex property allows many efficient algorithms, such as Alternate Convex Search (ACS) approach, to a achieve a guaranteed local optima[45]. E.g., we could iteratively solve KùêæK and Eùê∏E in the objective function (18) until we achieve the converged K‚àósuperscriptùêæ‚àóK^{\ast} and E‚àósuperscriptùê∏‚àóE^{\ast}. This optimization process corresponds to Lines¬†2‚Äì2 of Algorithm¬†2, where Lines¬†2 and 2 ensure that the solution is taken within the feasibility region, and Line¬†2 rounds the continuous values of KùêæK and Eùê∏E to integer values.

where the right hand side of (25) except for œµitalic-œµ\epsilon is bounded by some constant value, and thus the overhead ratio will be marginal for a high error precision with œµitalic-œµ\epsilon being small.

V Design Principles and Solution Properties for Cost Minimization

We theoretically analyze the solution properties for different optimization metrics and heterogeneous system parameters. The analysis not only provides insightful design principles but also gives alternative ways of solving Problem P3 more efficiently. Our empirical results in Section¬†VI show that these properties derived for Problem P3 are still valid for the original problem P1. For the ease of presentation, we consider continuous KùêæK and Eùê∏E (i.e., before rounding) in this section.

V-A Solution Property of KùêæK for Minimizing ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]

We first show how the normalized price factor Œ≥ùõæ\gamma affects the optimal solution of KùêæK. This provides useful design principles for choosing the number of participants for different optimization metrics, e.g., learning time or energy minimization.

Theorem 3.

For any fixed value of Eùê∏E, K‚àósuperscriptùêæ‚àóK^{\ast} decreases in Œ≥ùõæ\gamma. In particular, when Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1, ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] is a strictly increasing function in KùêæK, thus K‚àó=1superscriptùêæ‚àó1K^{\ast}=1.

The proof is given in Appendix¬†C. Theorem 3 shows that sampling fewer devices can reduce the total energy consumption for reaching the target loss (which would be the main objective as Œ≥ùõæ\gamma becomes large). While this may seem contradictory at the first glance, since a smaller KùêæK would result in more rounds to achieve the desired precision œµitalic-œµ\epsilon. The key intuition is that the total energy is the sum energy consumption of all selected clients. Although more rounds may cost longer learning time, there are also less number of clients participating in each round, so the total energy consumption can be smaller. Particularly, for pure energy minimization task (Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1) with K‚àó=1superscriptùêæ1K^{*}=1, our proposed sequential ordering scheduling in Theorem¬†1 reduces to uniformly at random sample one client for transmission in each round, which is a bit different compared to the Round-Robin scheme, because the sequence of our selected clients over several rounds is random not always following the same order.

Based on Theorem 3, we derive a trade-off design principle for KùêæK, generally, with a relatively larger121212We note that the main difference for reducing time cost between this work and wired FL in [1] is that the optimal K‚àósuperscriptùêæ‚àóK^{\ast} (for Œ≥=0ùõæ0\gamma=0) in [1] is always NùëÅN, where it is usually some value between [1,N]1ùëÅ[1,N] in this paper. KùêæK favoring learning time reduction (small Œ≥ùõæ\gamma) and a smaller KùêæK favoring energy saving (large Œ≥ùõæ\gamma). For a given Œ≥ùõæ\gamma, the optimal K‚àósuperscriptùêæ‚àóK^{\ast} achieves the best balance between learning time minimization and energy consumption minimization.

Next, we show how heterogeneous system parameters in terms of computation and communication affect the optimal solution of KùêæK. This shows which directions KùêæK and Eùê∏E should change to, when the system environment changes.

Theorem 4.

For any fixed value of Eùê∏E, when 0<Œ≥<10ùõæ10<\gamma<1, K‚àósuperscriptùêæ‚àóK^{\ast} increases in tpsubscriptùë°ùëùt_{p} and decreases in tmsubscriptùë°ùëöt_{m}, epsubscriptùëíùëùe_{p} and emsubscriptùëíùëöe_{m}. When Œ≥=0ùõæ0\gamma=0, K‚àósuperscriptùêæ‚àóK^{\ast} increases with tptmsubscriptùë°ùëùsubscriptùë°ùëö\frac{t_{p}}{t_{m}}; whereas when Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1, K‚àósuperscriptùêæ‚àóK^{\ast} is independent of emsubscriptùëíùëöe_{m} and epsubscriptùëíùëùe_{p}.

We give the proof in Appendix¬†D. Intuitively, for general 0‚â§Œ≥<10ùõæ10\leq\gamma<1, Theorem¬†4 says that when tmsubscriptùë°ùëöt_{m} increases (e.g., more clients suffering poor channel conditions or less system bandwidth is available), or emsubscriptùëíùëöe_{m} and epsubscriptùëíùëùe_{p} increases (higher average energy costs in communication or computation), the optimal strategy to reduce the total cost is to sample fewer clients. Interestingly, when the average computation time tpsubscriptùë°ùëùt_{p} increases, we should sample more clients. This is because, unlike the per-round communication time accumulated with more clients being sampled, the computation is performed in parallel among the sampled clients, which only slightly increases the per-round time. Sampling more clients can possibly reduce the required total number of rounds, thus bringing down the total learning time. When we only focus on energy minimization (Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1), the optimal KùêæK is independent of emsubscriptùëíùëöe_{m} and epsubscriptùëíùëùe_{p}, because Theorem 3 shows that K‚àó=1superscriptùêæ‚àó1K^{\ast}=1 in this case.

V-B Solution Property of Eùê∏E for Minimizing ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]

We first identify how the normalized price factor Œ≥ùõæ\gamma affects the choice of Eùê∏E for different optimization goals, e.g., learning time or energy minimization.

Theorem 5.

For any 0‚â§Œ≥‚â§10ùõæ10\leq\gamma\leq 1 and any fixed value of KùêæK, as Eùê∏E increases, ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] first decreases and then increases.

The proof is given in Appendix¬†E. Theorem¬†5 shows that, unlike the strategy for minimizing energy consumption where K‚àósuperscriptùêæ‚àóK^{\ast} lies at the boundary, the optimal Eùê∏E should not be set too small nor too large no matter for saving energy consumption or learning time.

Then, the following theorem characterizes how heterogeneous system parameters in computation and communication affect the design principle of optimal Eùê∏E.

Theorem 6.

For any fixed value of Eùê∏E, when 0<Œ≥<10ùõæ10<\gamma<1, E‚àósuperscriptùê∏‚àóE^{\ast} increases as tpsubscriptùë°ùëùt_{p} or epsubscriptùëíùëùe_{p} decreases. E‚àósuperscriptùê∏E^{*} increases in tmtpsubscriptùë°ùëösubscriptùë°ùëù\frac{t_{m}}{t_{p}} when Œ≥=0ùõæ0\gamma=0, and E‚àósuperscriptùê∏E^{*} increases in emepsubscriptùëíùëösubscriptùëíùëù\frac{e_{m}}{e_{p}} when Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1.

We give the proof in Appendix¬†F. Theorem¬†6 says that for any given KùêæK, when or tpsubscriptùë°ùëùt_{p} or epsubscriptùëíùëùe_{p} decreases, the optimal strategy for learning time minimization (Œ≥=0ùõæ0\gamma=0) or energy consumption minimization (Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1) is to perform more steps of iterations (i.e., increase Eùê∏E) before aggregation. This is because when computation is cheaper or when communication is more expensive, it is beneficial to perform more computation in each round, as intuition suggests. This theorem provides theoretical evidence for the empirical observations in [7, 16, 17, 15].

VI Experimental Evaluation

In this section, we evaluate the performance of our proposed scheduling scheme, cost-effective FL algorithm and derived solution properties. We start by presenting the evaluation setup, and then show the experimental results.

VI-A Experimental Setup

VI-A1 Platforms

We conducted experiments both on a networked hardware prototype system and in a simulated environment. Our prototype system, as illustrated in Fig.¬†2, consists of 30 edge devices with 202020 Raspberry Pis (version 4) and 101010 Jetson Nanos as well as a laptop computer serving as the central server. All devices are interconnected via an enterprise Wi-Fi router, and we developed a TCP-based socket interface for the peer-to-peer connection.131313To characterize LTE-based wireless networks as in Fig.¬†1, we manually change the original communication protocol in our TS-based WiFi system, so that all devices start their local training at the same time and without calculating the downlink time. In the simulation system, we simulated a cellular network of an urban microcell consisting of a central BS serving as the server and N=100ùëÅ100N=100 clients. The BS and server were co-located at the center of the cell with a radius of 222 km, and the clients were uniformly distributed in the cell.

VI-A2 Datasets and Models

We evaluate our results both on a real dataset and a synthetic dataset. For the real dataset, following a same setup of [46], we adopted the widely used MNIST dataset and EMNIST dataset, which contains gray-scale images of handwritten digits and characters. For the synthetic dataset, we follow a similar setup to that in [21], which generates 606060-dimensional random vectors as input data. The synthetic data is denoted by S‚Äãy‚Äãn‚Äãt‚Äãh‚Äãe‚Äãt‚Äãi‚Äãc‚Äã(Œ±,Œ≤)ùëÜùë¶ùëõùë°‚Ñéùëíùë°ùëñùëêùõºùõΩSynthetic\ (\alpha,\beta) with Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta representing the statistical heterogeneity (i.e., how non-i.i.d. the data are). We adopt the convex multinomial logistic regression model for both datasets with model size around 0.030.030.03 MB [10].

VI-A3 Implementation

Based on the above, we consider the following three experimental setups with heterogeneous data distribution.

Prototype Setup: We conduct the first experiment on the prototype system using MNIST dataset, where we divide 9,00090009,000 data samples among the N=30ùëÅ30N\!=\!30 edge devices (20 Raspberry Pis and 10 Jetson Nanos) in a non-i.i.d. fashion, with each device containing a balanced number of 300300300 samples of only 222 digit labels.

Simulation Setup 1: We conduct the second experiment in the simulated system using EMNIST dataset, where we divide 48,000 image samples among N=100ùëÅ100N=100 clients in a non-i.i.d. fashion, with each client containing a balanced number of 480 samples of only 2 classes.

Simulation Setup 2: We conduct the third experiment in the simulated system using S‚Äãy‚Äãn‚Äãt‚Äãh‚Äãe‚Äãt‚Äãi‚Äãc‚Äã(1,1)ùëÜùë¶ùëõùë°‚Ñéùëíùë°ùëñùëê11Synthetic\ (1,1) dataset for statistical heterogeneity. We generate 24,5172451724,517 data samples and distribute them among N=100ùëÅ100N\!=\!100 mobile devices in an unbalanced power law distribution, where the number of samples in each device has a mean of 245245245 and standard deviation of 362362362.

VI-A4 Training Parameters

For all experiments, we initialize our model with ùê∞0=ùüésubscriptùê∞00\mathbf{w}_{0}=\mathbf{0} and SGD batch size b=64ùëè64b=64. In each round, we uniformly sample KùêæK devices at random, which run Eùê∏E steps of SGD in parallel. For all experiments, we use an initial learning rate Œ∑0=0.1subscriptùúÇ00.1\eta_{0}=0.1 with decay rate Œ∑01+rsubscriptùúÇ01ùëü\frac{{\eta}_{0}}{1+r}, where rùëür is communication round index. We evaluate the aggregated model in each round on the global loss function. Each result is averaged over 50 experiments.

VI-A5 Heterogeneous System Parameters

The prototype system allows us to capture real system heterogeneity in terms of communication and computation time, which we measured the average tp=4.9√ó10‚àí3subscriptùë°ùëù4.9superscript103t_{p}=4.9\times 10^{-3} s with standard deviation 1.43√ó10‚àí31.43superscript1031.43\times 10^{-3} s and tm=0.16subscriptùë°ùëö0.16t_{m}=0.16¬†s with standard deviation 0.030.030.03 s. We do not consider the energy cost in the prototype system because it is difficult to measure. For the simulated mobile edge system, we assume the system bandwidth is 1.8 MHz and adopt the standard LTE communications model based on a well-known urban channel model with the mean per-client throughput 1.41.41.4¬†Mbit/s (thus tm‚âà0.2subscriptùë°ùëö0.2t_{m}\approx 0.2¬†s) as in [29]. We generate the computation time and energy consumption for each client using a truncated normal distribution with mean value of tp=0.5subscriptùë°ùëù0.5t_{p}\!=\!0.5¬†s (emulating slow devices), ep=0.01subscriptùëíùëù0.01e_{p}=0.01¬†J, and em=0.02subscriptùëíùëö0.02e_{m}=0.02¬†J . According to the definition of Œ≥ùõæ\gamma, we unify the time and energy costs such that one second is equivalent to 1‚àíŒ≥1ùõæ1-\gamma dollars¬†($) and one Joule is equivalent to Œ≥ùõæ\gamma dollars¬†($).

VI-B Performance Results

In this subsection, we first evaluate the performance of our proposed TS scheduling strategy with two existing benchmarks. Then, we compare the performance of the proposed solution (K‚àósuperscriptùêæK^{*}, E‚àósuperscriptùê∏E^{*}) obtained from Algorithm¬†2 for solving Problem P3, with that of the empirical optimal solution (KOPTsubscriptùêæOPTK_{\textnormal{OPT}}, EOPTsubscriptùê∏OPTE_{\textnormal{OPT}}) achieved by an exhaustive search on the optimal solution of the original problem P1. Finally, we validate our derived design principles and solution properties.

VI-B1 Scheduling Performance

Fig.¬†3 compares the total learning time performance of our proposed TS scheduling with the following two benchmarks in Prototype Setup:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Benchmark 1: existing TS scheduling strategy in [13], where communication does not begin until all sampled clients complete their local computations.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Benchmark 2: existing FS scheduling strategy in [30, 27, 36], where the algorithm allocates the bandwidth at the start of each round for the sampled clients, then the bandwidth allocation remains unchanged throughout the round and every selected client starts its communication using its allocated bandwidth whenever its computation has finished.

The main observations are as follows.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Fig.¬†3 demonstrates that our proposed scheduling strategy in Theorem 1 achieves the target loss faster than the two benchmarks, since our method can better utilize system resources and adapt to both computation and communication heterogeneity.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The performance gaps between our scheme and the two benchmarks increase in Eùê∏E at first and then remain stable in Fig.¬†3(b). The reason for this observation is that, as Eùê∏E increases, the computation times between different sampled clients are more different, allowing our scheme to better utilize the full bandwidth and thus save per-round time. When Eùê∏E is large enough, the per-round time is only dominated by computation time, hence the impact of different scheduling is insignificant as scheduling mainly affects the communication time.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We also observe that the performance gaps between our scheme and the two benchmarks increase in KùêæK at first and then remain stable in Fig.¬†3(c). The explanation for this observation is that as KùêæK increases, the difference between the maximum and minimum computation time among the selected KùêæK clients can be larger, allowing our scheme to better utilize the computational heterogeneity, e.g., communication could begin at an early stage instead of waiting for the rest clients. When KùêæK is large enough, the per-round time is mainly dominated by communication time, and the gain from computational heterogeneity tends to be stable between different scheduling schemes.

VI-B2 Optimality Performance

We first present the estimation process and results of A0B0subscriptùê¥0subscriptùêµ0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}} for the three experiment setups in Table¬†III. The key observations are as follows.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Fig.¬†4 shows the learning time cost TtotsubscriptùëátotT_{\textnormal{tot}} for reaching the target loss under different (K,E)ùêæùê∏\left(K,E\right) for Prototype Setup.161616For hardware prototype, we only show the convergence performance with TtotsubscriptùëátotT_{\textnormal{tot}} for Œ≥=0ùõæ0\gamma=0. In particular, our solution achieves the target loss using 66.266.266.2 s compared to the empirical optimum 61.761.761.7 s, whereas other (KùêæK, Eùê∏E) pairs without optimization may consume a learning time that is several folds more, as shown in Fig.¬†4(c).171717The intersections in Fig. 4(c) and Fig. 5(d) show that, for a given Eùê∏E, different numbers of KùêæK may result in the same total learning time. This is because the trade-off between the total number of rounds for reaching the target loss and the per-round time, as a large KùêæK reduces the number of rounds but yields a longer per-round time, whereas a small KùêæK reduces the per-round time but requires more rounds.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Fig.¬†5 depicts the energy cost etotsubscriptùëítote_{\textnormal{tot}} for reaching the target loss under different (K,E)ùêæùê∏\left(K,E\right) for Simulation Setup 1. Our solution achieves the target loss and accuracy with the similar energy cost compared to the empirical optimal solution, and saves several folds of energy compared to those (KùêæK, Eùê∏E) pairs without optimization.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Figs.¬†6 shows the total cost Ctotsubscriptùê∂totC_{\textnormal{tot}} for reaching the target loss for different Œ≥ùõæ\gamma under different (K,E)ùêæùê∏\left(K,\ E\right) for Simulation Setup 2. Comparing to other (KùêæK, Eùê∏E) pairs without optimization in Fig.¬†6(c)-(f), our proposed solutions incur a similar total cost as the corresponding empirical optimal ones through the entire range of Œ≥ùõæ\gamma.

VI-B3 Property Validation

We highlight that our derived theoretical properties of KùêæK and Eùê∏E can be validated empirically in both prototype and simulation experiments. Particularly, we manually decrease tpsubscriptùë°ùëùt_{p} and epsubscriptùëíùëùe_{p} in Simulation Setup 2, and shows how system parameters affect the design principles in Fig.¬†7. We summarize the key results as follows.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We observe from Figs.¬†6(d)-6(e) that the optimal KùêæK decreases from 10 to 1 as Œ≥ùõæ\gamma increases from 0 to 1. Particularly, we see from Figs.¬†5(c) and 6(e) that, when Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1, the energy cost strictly increases in KùêæK, with KOPT=1subscriptùêæOPT1K_{\textnormal{OPT}}=1. These observations confirm our claim in Theorem¬†3.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Figs.¬†4(c), 5(c), 6(c)‚Äì6(e) demonstrate that for any fixed value of KùêæK, the corresponding total cost first decreases and then increases as Eùê∏E increases, which confirms our Theorem¬†5.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Comparing Fig.¬†7(a) with Fig.¬†6(d), we observe that for a fixed value of Eùê∏E, the optimal KùêæK decreases as tpsubscriptùë°ùëùt_{p} decreases. For example, for E=26ùê∏26E=26, the optimal KùêæK decreases from 101010 to 222 as tpsubscriptùë°ùëùt_{p} decreases, which confirms Theorem¬†4.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Comparing Fig.¬†7(b) with Fig.¬†6(e), for fixed value of KùêæK, the optimal Eùê∏E increases as epsubscriptùëíùëùe_{p} decreases, e.g., for K=1ùêæ1K\!=\!1, the optimal Eùê∏E increases from 14 to 20, which confirms Theorem¬†6.

VII Conclusion

In this work, we have studied the cost-effective design for federated learning in mobile edge networks. We proposed a new time-sharing scheduling scheme which captures system heterogeneity in terms of computation and wireless communication, and analyzed how to optimally choose the number of participating clients (KùêæK) and the number of local iterations (Eùê∏E), which are two essential control variables in FL, to minimize the total cost while ensuring convergence. We proposed a sampling-based control algorithm which efficiently solves the optimization problem with marginal overhead. We also derived insightful solution properties which helps identify the design principles for different optimization goals, e.g., reducing learning time or saving energy. Extensive experimentation results validated our theoretical analysis and demonstrated the effectiveness and efficiency of our control algorithm. Our optimization design is orthogonal to most works on resource allocation for FL systems, e.g, transmission power or CPU frequency, and can be used together with those techniques to further reduce the cost.

Appendix B Proof of Lemma 2

Since the KùêæK clients are sampled uniformly at random in each round without replacement, the ‚Äúfirst‚Äù scheduling client is mink‚ààùí¶r‚Å°{tk,p}subscriptùëòsuperscriptùí¶ùëüsubscriptùë°ùëòùëù\min_{k\in\mathcal{K}^{r}}\{t_{k,p}\}. Thus, in the reordered sequence (11), those who could be served as the first are the {1,2,‚Ä¶,N‚àíK+1}12‚Ä¶ùëÅùêæ1\{1,2,\ldots,N\!-\!K\!+\!1\}th clients.

The probability of client i‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶,N‚àíK+1}ùëñ12‚Ä¶ùëÅùêæ1i\in\{1,2,\ldots,N-K+1\} being the ‚Äúfirst‚Äù client is CN‚àíiK‚àí1CNKsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùëñùêæ1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùêæ\frac{{C_{N-i}^{K-1}}}{C_{N}^{K}}, where CNKsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùêæC_{N}^{K} is the number of all possible KùêæK clients combinations, CN‚àíkK‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùëòùêæ1{C_{N-k}^{K-1}} is the number of KùêæK clients combinations with client iùëñi being the ‚Äúfirst‚Äù (fast) client. In other words, the rest K‚àí1ùêæ1K-1 clients must be taken from the behind the N‚àíKùëÅùêæN-K clients who placed behind client kùëòk. Therefore, the expected time of the ‚Äúfirst‚Äù client is

ùîº‚Äã[mink‚ààùí¶r‚Å°{tk,p‚ÄãE}]=‚àëi=1N‚àíK+1CN‚àíiK‚àí1‚Äãti,pCNK‚ÄãE.ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëòsuperscriptùí¶ùëüsubscriptùë°ùëòùëùùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅùêæ1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùëñùêæ1subscriptùë°ùëñùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùêæùê∏\mathbb{E}[\min_{k\in\mathcal{K}^{r}}\{t_{k,p}E\}]=\frac{\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N-K+1}{C_{N-i}^{K-1}}t_{i,p}}{C_{N}^{K}}E. (34)

Then, similar to the proof in Lemma 1, for uniform at random sampling, the probability of each client being sampled in each round is KNùêæùëÅ\frac{K}{N}. Thus. we have

ùîº‚Äã[‚àëk=1Ktk,mr]=ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëöùëüabsent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\sum_{k=1}^{K}t_{k,m}^{r}]= KN‚Äãùîº‚Äã[‚àëi=1Nti,mr]ùêæùëÅùîºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëñùëöùëü\displaystyle\frac{K}{N}\mathbb{E}[\sum_{i=1}^{N}t_{i,m}^{r}] (35)
=\displaystyle= K‚Äã‚àëi=1Nùîº‚Äã[ti,mr]N=K‚Äã‚àëi=iNt¬Øi,mN=tm‚ÄãK.ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅùîºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùë°ùëñùëöùëüùëÅùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëñùëñùëÅsubscript¬Øùë°ùëñùëöùëÅsubscriptùë°ùëöùêæ\displaystyle K\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}\mathbb{E}[t_{i,m}^{r}]}{N}=K\frac{\sum_{i=i}^{N}\overline{t}_{i,m}}{N}=t_{m}K.

Given that the computation time and communication time are independent, the approximate per-round time in (10) can be expressed as

ùîº‚Äã[Tr]=ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptùëáùëüabsent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[T^{r}]= ùîº‚Äã[mink‚ààùí¶r‚Å°{tk,p‚ÄãE}]+ùîº‚Äã[‚àëk=1Ktk,mr]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëòsuperscriptùí¶ùëüsubscriptùë°ùëòùëùùê∏ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëöùëü\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\min_{k\in\mathcal{K}^{r}}\{t_{k,p}E\}]+\mathbb{E}[\sum_{k=1}^{K}t_{k,m}^{r}] (36)
=\displaystyle= ‚àëi=1N‚àíK+1CN‚àíiK‚àí1‚Äãti,pCNK‚ÄãE+tm‚ÄãK.superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅùêæ1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùëñùêæ1subscriptùë°ùëñùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëÅùêæùê∏subscriptùë°ùëöùêæ\displaystyle\frac{\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{N-K+1}{C_{N-i}^{K-1}}t_{i,p}}{C_{N}^{K}}E+t_{m}K.

Therefore, (12) can be obtained for RùëÖR round communications, which concludes this proof.

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 3

Taking the first order derivative of ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] over KùêæK for any given Eùê∏E, we have

‚àÇùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]‚àÇK=~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂totùêæabsent\displaystyle\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K}= [(1‚àíŒ≥)‚Äãtm+Œ≥‚Äã(ep‚ÄãE+em)]‚Äã(A0E+B0‚Äã(N‚àí2)‚ÄãEN‚àí1)delimited-[]1ùõæsubscriptùë°ùëöùõæsubscriptùëíùëùùê∏subscriptùëíùëösubscriptùê¥0ùê∏subscriptùêµ0ùëÅ2ùê∏ùëÅ1\displaystyle\left[(1\!-\!\gamma)t_{m}+\gamma\left(e_{p}E\!+\!{e_{m}}\right)\right]\left(\frac{A_{0}}{E}+\frac{B_{0}(N\!-\!2)E}{N\!-\!1}\right) (37)
‚àí(1‚àíŒ≥)‚ÄãB0‚ÄãN‚Äãtp‚ÄãE2(N‚àí1)‚ÄãK2.1ùõæsubscriptùêµ0ùëÅsubscriptùë°ùëùsuperscriptùê∏2ùëÅ1superscriptùêæ2\displaystyle-\frac{(1\!-\!\gamma)B_{0}Nt_{p}E^{2}}{(N\!-\!1)K^{2}}.

When Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1, ‚àÇùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]‚àÇK~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂totùêæ\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K} is always positive, thus, K‚àó=1superscriptùêæ‚àó1K^{\ast}=1. However, when 0‚â§Œ≥<10ùõæ10\leq\gamma<1, ‚àÇùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]‚àÇK~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂totùêæ\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K} is negative for small KùêæK and positive for large KùêæK. Thus, as KùêæK increases, ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] first decreases and then increases, thus K‚àó‚àà[1,N]superscriptùêæ‚àó1ùëÅK^{\ast}\in[1,N]. By letting ‚àÇùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]‚àÇK=0~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂totùêæ0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K}=0, and dividing (1‚àíŒ≥)1ùõæ(1-\gamma), we concludes that K‚àósuperscriptùêæ‚àóK^{\ast} decreases as Œ≥ùõæ\gamma due to the fact that Œ≥(1‚àíŒ≥)ùõæ1ùõæ\frac{\gamma}{(1-\gamma)} is an increasing function in Œ≥ùõæ\gamma.

Appendix D Proof of Theorem 4

Following the proof in Appendix C, we let ‚àÇùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]‚àÇK=0~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂totùêæ0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K}=0. Then, it is straightforward to obtain that, for any given Eùê∏E and 0<Œ≥<10ùõæ10<\gamma<1, the optimal KùêæK increases in tpsubscriptùë°ùëùt_{p} while decreases in tmsubscriptùë°ùëöt_{m}, emsubscriptùëíùëöe_{m}, and epsubscriptùëíùëùe_{p}. In particular, according to Theorem 3, when Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1, K‚àó=1superscriptùêæ‚àó1K^{\ast}=1 and thus is independent with emsubscriptùëíùëöe_{m} and epsubscriptùëíùëùe_{p}.

Appendix E Proof of Theorem 5

Taking the first order derivative of ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] over Eùê∏E for any given KùêæK, we have

‚àÇùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]‚àÇE~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂totùê∏\displaystyle\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial E} =B0‚Äã[(1‚àíŒ≥)‚Äã(2‚Äãtp‚ÄãE+tm‚ÄãK)+Œ≥‚ÄãK‚Äã(2‚Äãep‚ÄãE+em)]absentsubscriptùêµ0delimited-[]1ùõæ2subscriptùë°ùëùùê∏subscriptùë°ùëöùêæùõæùêæ2subscriptùëíùëùùê∏subscriptùëíùëö\displaystyle=B_{0}\left[(1\!-\!\gamma)\left(2t_{p}E\!+\!t_{m}K\right)\!+\!\gamma K(2e_{p}E\!+\!e_{m})\right] (38)
‚ãÖ(1+N‚àíKK‚Äã(N‚àí1))‚àíA0‚ÄãK‚Äã[(1‚àíŒ≥)‚Äãtm+Œ≥‚Äãem]E2.‚ãÖabsent1ùëÅùêæùêæùëÅ1subscriptùê¥0ùêædelimited-[]1ùõæsubscriptùë°ùëöùõæsubscriptùëíùëösuperscriptùê∏2\displaystyle\cdot\left(1\!+\!\frac{N\!-\!K}{K(N\!-\!1)}\!\right)-\frac{A_{0}K[(1\!-\!\gamma)t_{m}\!+\!\gamma e_{m}]}{E^{2}}.

For any 0‚â§Œ≥‚â§10ùõæ10\leq\gamma\leq 1, and any feasible KùêæK, (38) is negative when Eùê∏E is small and positive when Eùê∏E is large. Thus, as Eùê∏E increases, ùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] first decreases and then increases.

Appendix F Proof of Theorem 6

Following the proof in Appendix E, we let ‚àÇùîº~‚Äã[Ctot]‚àÇE=0~ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùê∂totùê∏0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial E}=0. Then, we have

[(1‚àíŒ≥)‚Äã(2‚Äãtp‚ÄãE3+tm‚ÄãK‚ÄãE2)+Œ≥‚ÄãK‚Äã(2‚Äãep‚ÄãE3+em‚ÄãE2)]K‚Äã[(1‚àíŒ≥)‚Äãtm+Œ≥‚Äãem]delimited-[]1ùõæ2subscriptùë°ùëùsuperscriptùê∏3subscriptùë°ùëöùêæsuperscriptùê∏2ùõæùêæ2subscriptùëíùëùsuperscriptùê∏3subscriptùëíùëösuperscriptùê∏2ùêædelimited-[]1ùõæsubscriptùë°ùëöùõæsubscriptùëíùëö\displaystyle\frac{\left[(1\!-\!\gamma)\left(2t_{p}E^{3}\!+\!t_{m}KE^{2}\right)\!+\!\gamma K(2e_{p}E^{3}\!+\!e_{m}E^{2})\right]}{K[(1\!-\!\gamma)t_{m}\!+\!\gamma e_{m}]} (39)
=A0B0‚Äã(1+N‚àíKK‚Äã(N‚àí1)).absentsubscriptùê¥0subscriptùêµ01ùëÅùêæùêæùëÅ1\displaystyle=\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}\left(1\!+\!\frac{N\!-\!K}{K(N\!-\!1)}\!\right)}.

Thus, it is straightforward to see that the solution of Eùê∏E increases as tpsubscriptùë°ùëùt_{p} or epsubscriptùëíùëùe_{p} decreases.

In particular, when Œ≥=0ùõæ0\gamma=0, the solution of Eùê∏E increases in tmtpsubscriptùë°ùëösubscriptùë°ùëù\frac{t_{m}}{t_{p}}. Similarly, when Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1, the solution of Eùê∏E increases in emepsubscriptùëíùëösubscriptùëíùëù\frac{e_{m}}{e_{p}}.
